With an introduction by David Mitchell

Isserley spends most of her time driving. But why is she so interested in picking up hitchhikers? And why are they always male, well-built and alone?

An utterly unpredictable and macabre mystery, Under the Skin is a genre-defying masterpiece.

From the Publisher

Read more
Read more

Michel Faber has written nine other books. In addition to the Whitbread-shortlisted Under the Skin, he is the author of the highly acclaimed The Crimson Petal and the White, The Book of Strange New Things, which was shortlisted for the Arthur C. Clarke Award and won the Saltire Book of the Year Award 2015, and most recently Undying, his first poetry collection. Born in Holland, brought up in Australia, he now lives in the UK.

Product description

Review

"A wonderful book - painful, lyrical, frightening, brilliant . . . I couldn't put it down" -- Kate Atkinson

"One of the best-orchestrated reveals in modern British fiction . . . Michel Faber is a masterly writer" -- David Mitchell

"Profound and disturbing . . . Faber writes superbly" ― Sunday Times

"This is a man who could give Conrad a run at writing the perfect sentence" ― Guardian

"Teases and prods the reader up a plethora of literary blind alleys before hauling them screaming towards its final, thrilling destination" ― Daily Telegraph

"Strange, adept, original . . . Would that more first novels were as adventurous or as funky and daring in their conception" ― Independent on Sunday

"A brilliantly compressed drama of threat and ambiguity . . . Recalling writers such as Jim Crace and Russell Hoban, Under the Skin, like Faber's short stories, is an extremely assured and imaginative work" ― Observer

"Astonishingly, this is Michel Faber's first novel. It is audacious, fascinating, repellent and quite unlike anything I have ever read" ― Mail on Sunday

"Under the Skin is a shocking and fantastical take on modern humanity" ― The Week

"The fantastic is so nicely played against the day-to-day that one feels the strangeness of both . . . A remarkable novel" ― New York Times

Book Description

One of Michel Faber's best-loved novels, this is an utterly compulsive and mysterious masterpiece

About the Author

Michel Faber has written nine books. In addition to the Whitbread-shortlisted Under the Skin, he is the author of the highly acclaimed The Crimson Petal and the White, The Book of Strange New Things, which was shortlisted for the Arthur C, Clarke Award and won the 2015 Saltire Book of the Year, and most recently Undying, his first poetry collection. Born in Holland, brought up in Australia, he now lives in the UK.

How customer reviews and ratings work

Customer Reviews, including Product Star Ratings, help customers to learn more about the product and decide whether it is the right product for them.

To calculate the overall star rating and percentage breakdown by star, we don’t use a simple average. Instead, our system considers things like how recent a review is and if the reviewer bought the item on Amazon. It also analyses reviews to verify trustworthiness.

RB
5.0 out of 5 stars If I had a top-ten best novels I’ve ever read, this would be in it, easily
Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 19 August 2021
Verified Purchase
I’m quite amazed that it’s not 5 stars from everyone, but I’ll speculate as to the possible reasons for this, to try to convince those who might love it, to read it.

I am genuinely envious of anyone getting to read it for the first time. About 2/3 through I went back and re-read the first third to get to enjoy the suspense a bit longer; I read the entire novel in 2 days.

This is my third full-length Michael Faber novel with only one non-Faber novel in between - I even read some of his short stories (and I don’t like short stories in general) just because I can’t believe I’ve only just discovered this author.

I would not have picked up this novel based on the blurb - the wonders within cannot be gleened from it unless you already know the author. Apart from the very occasional annoying non-British word or phrase (it’s set in Scotland but Faber is multi-national and his British characters occasionally say American things), the writing is superb. I’m trying to think why someone wouldn’t gobble up this novel… it is philosophical, the author has a mind that wonders in a way that mine does, and in fact this novel’s premise is a established philosophical thought experiment. If you’re not philosophically-inclined, you might not like it (or maybe you will still! I hope so!) But it’s absolutely nothing like those Michael Haigh books - Faber hasn’t got his philosophy from Wikipedia, he’s likely not even aware of the connections, he’s just got an inquiring, interesting mind.

But on top of that, I’ve never found an author who so wonderfully sets up a mystery - I wondered many things but I still didn’t land on the answer in advance, and even better, rather than being tempted to flick through to the end to find out I re-read from the start to eek it out - it’s not just that you don’t know, it’s that finding out is a delicious unfolding.

It’s a wonderful novel, perhaps aimed more towards those who enjoy the sort of novels studied in English Lit classes at school over the sort of novels that have covers with titles in white capital letters that take up nearly the whole page (don’t judge a book by it’s cover, but judge from
a book’s cover the intended audience of the publishers - it’s a pretty good guide!) I was completely hooked from the first chapter. I wish he had written 40 novels already for me to read! But I realise that his genius means he can’t churn them out….

My new favourite author.

Norman Housley
4.0 out of 5 stars Isserley's progress (read this only if you know the novel's premise)
Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 10 November 2014
Verified Purchase
SPOILERS
I didn't take to Michel Faber's work initially - I found The Crimson Petal and the White laboured and over-written, but I have really enjoyed both of his 'alien' books, this and The Book of Strange New Things. In both novels he explores the famous E.M. Forster dictum, 'only connect', but in strikingly and refreshingly different ways. In both books you really have to live with a lot of implausible background if you are going to enjoy what Faber has to say - it is simply pointless adding up all the reasons why the circumstances of Isserley's bizarre work don't make sense. The point is the effect on her, and how the visit by Amlis Vess acts as the catalyst for a radical shift in her moral perspective which makes her act as she does towards the end. This is very subtly done and she is transformed from being a cold and unsympathetic protagonist into an individual whose decisions and fate we care about.
In a couple of respects Faber disappointed me. First, the ending doesn't flow from the book's narrative. It's almost as if he ran out of ideas. Secondly, and more importantly, the change effected by Vess isn't really plausible. I couldn't accept that a person as intelligent and sensitive as Isserley would be able to segment her life as she did - the reason being that the society she sees every day outside the farm is so similar to that of her home planet. When Faber engages with this issue, listing several ways in which the world of 'human beings' differs from that of the vodsels, he dodges the question, simply providing a few made up words for things that in Isserley's eyes make her people superior to her prey. That doesn't work because everything we are told about the home planet in the book makes Isserley's people sound just as bad as the vodsels if not worse (it appears that they have comprehensively trashed their environment and are stuck with an inflexible two-tier social system).
Still, this remains a very interesting and superbly written book about difference, the wonder of the natural world, loneliness and grief ... and the perils of hitch-hiking, especially in Ross-shire, where the police don't appear even to notice dozens of men disappearing.
